An IRS Agent will ALWAYS provide identification when requested. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D4W3jlxXoAEhaT8.jpg
The IRS will NEVER initiate contact by email or text message to request personal or financial information.
The IRS will NEVER threaten to bring in local police or other law-enforcement groups to have you arrested for not paying.
The IRS will NEVER ask for credit or debit card numbers over the phone.
The IRS will NEVER require you to use a specific payment method for your taxes, such as a prepaid debit card or cash.
The IRS will NEVER demand that you pay taxes without giving you the opportunity to question or appeal the amount they say you owe.
Remember: The IRS will NEVER call to demand immediate payment, or call about taxes owed without first having mailed you a bill. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D4W2qhiXsAEgHqT.jpg

Past tragedies have made it horrifically clear what can happen when we choose to divide, classify, and target others based on their religion, or skin tone, or accent. Our visit to the @VaHolocaust Museum reminded me of why I am proud to be an original cosponsor on the #NoBanAct.

From this vantage point you can see there are stretches of the border with no physical barrier between Mexico and United States. #BuildTheWall @realdonaldtrump http://pbs.twimg.com/ext_tw_video_thumb/1118584439100067841/pu/img/OMw2zHi9Hi6flZEm.jpg https://video.twimg.com/ext_tw_video/1118584439100067841/pu/vid/220x180/sESJp4V06gozjtfN.mp4?tag=8
These common elements are EVERYWHERE in modern America, not just in our history books.

Look at the story of the Gross Breesen students ‚Äì the anxiety about whether they have the skills needed to relocate. The rise of hatred & persecution against a religious minority. The persistent battle to obtain a visa. The depth of patriotism for an adopted nation.

The @VaHolocaust Museum does the critically important work of teaching us about the past, but they also bring these issues into the present. Human rights violations are occurring every day, in every corner of the globe.

During our visit, we also spent time with a Holocaust survivor and heard his family‚Äôs compelling story of survival. I had met him previously, but this was the first time I had the opportunity to hear his entire story. It is a chance I am deeply thankful for.
The Gross Breesen students and the Thalhimer family remained in contact for many years.

Hyde Farmlands was eventually sold, but the students went on to serve in the U.S. military as soldiers and linguists during the war. Some of them experienced the liberation of Buchenwald concentration camp, where they themselves had been prisoners just a few years before.

In 1939-1940, after a lengthy legal battle, the Thalhimer family of Richmond succeeded in securing visas for 21 Gross Breesen students. On the eve of World War II, these Jewish students arrived in Central Virginia from Germany and founded Hyde Farmlands.

In 1936, the German Jewish community created an agricultural training institute called Gross Breesen to teach Jewish young people skills they might need to successfully flee the country as the Nazis gained power.

Yesterday, I joined the students of Matoaka Middle School for their tour of the @VaHolocaust Museum. We learned the incredible story of Hyde Farmlands, which was located in Burkeville in #VA07's Nottoway County. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/D4YAqiLWkAQKtNF.jpg
